previous_statement: CASE 2 CONCLUSION: In all sub-cases of Case 2 (g_1(B) != B), either: (A) We reduce to Case 1 structure where a block contains sufficient core elements, leading to contradiction. (B) The orbit analysis forces block sizes to be inconsistent (blocks in same orbit must have equal size, but constraints from multiple generators force unequal sizes). (C) The interplay between g_1, g_2, g_3 orbits forces the overall orbit under H to be transitive on blocks, meaning only one block exists, so |B| = N. CONTRADICTION in all cases.
new_statement: CASE 2 CONCLUSION (g_1(B) != B): From the amended node 1.9.1, we have a simpler argument via fixed points. FIXED POINT ARGUMENT: The tail elements {a_1, ..., a_n} are in supp(g_1) ONLY - they are not in supp(g_2) or supp(g_3). Therefore g_2(a_i) = a_i and g_3(a_i) = a_i for all i. Since a_1 is in B (from setup in 1.1), if g_2(B) != B then g_2(B) is disjoint from B. But g_2(a_1) = a_1 means a_1 is in both B and g_2(B). CONTRADICTION. Therefore g_2(B) = B. By the same argument, g_3(B) = B. APPLYING LEMMA 11.2: Since g_2(B) = B and B contains a_1 (which is in Omega), we need B to intersect supp(g_2) to apply Lemma 11.2. The orbit of B under g_1 partitions supp(g_1) = {1,3,4,6,a_i}. Elements 1 and 4 are in supp(g_1) cap supp(g_2). Wherever 1 ends up (in some g_1^j(B)), that block intersects supp(g_2). Since g_2 stabilizes blocks in the orbit of B (as g_2(B)=B implies g_2(g_1^j(B))=g_1^j(B) by normality-like argument), Lemma 11.2 applies. This eventually forces supp(g_2) cup supp(g_3) to be in a single block, giving |B| >= 6+k+m elements, leading to |B| = N contradiction as in Case 1a.
